intro: Mattiastrum paphlagonicum, commonly known as the Paphlagonian sedge, is a flowering plant native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and grass-like plants. The plant typically grows in wet or moist habitats such as marshes, stream banks, and wet meadows. It has slender, triangular stems and produces small, clustered inflorescences with inconspicuous flowers. Its botanical features make it an important species for wetland ecosystems and botanical studies.
